text: how we learn as little as it appears to
be the case given the enormous amount of
money we've spent in Afghanistan well
you and I were equally observers of this
money as it was spent until january
twenty first of this year when the
president asked me to take on this job
was the money wasted yes some of it was
and I've been on the record as saying
that and I'm willing to be specific on
some of the things I said publicly as a
private citizen none of which I would
retract but it was an entirely wasted
the country was in the grips of the
Taliban before the American troops
arrived they were driven out they've
been vast areas of the country have
improved dramatically women have been
given opportunities which were
unimaginable under the Taliban but still
not where we think they ought to be
health programs are working well the
education system has been rebuilt many
most parts of the country actually don't
have much fighting in them having said
that the so-called pashtoon belt the
south and east which borders on Pakistan
is very very difficult situation right
now and if any of you are interested in
it read Dexter Filkins extraordinary
article in The New York Times on Tuesday
of this week in which he got caught in a
firefight in the poppy fields near
Kandahar an amazing piece of journalism
and and you'll see how tough it is so I
wouldn't say all the money was wasted
the real problem however is that is not
in Afghanistan Afghanistan is tough and
I'm happy to talk about it but the
really tough problem is next door
because when the American troops drove
the Taliban East at the end of right
after 911 and the going after al qaeda
al qaeda slipped across the board
as we all know and the Taliban
leadership went with them and they
nested in western Pakistan in the tribal
areas this remote difficult area and
then gradually they looked ron said hey
this is pretty fertile ground and first
they were just resting recovering
rebuilding and sending forays into
Afghanistan that looks now like the
Golden Age 2002 2003 the administration
then in power made the decision to
divert its resources to Iraq that's why
senator Obama during the campaign said
correctly we took our eye off the ball
that was a correct statement and Hillary
Clinton said the same thing and so the
situation began to deteriorate just as
the Taliban wasn't wrenching itself in
western Pakistan and in western Pakistan
the situation is much more difficult
because the United States cannot put
troops into Western Pakistan Pakistanis
don't want it and personally I don't
think it would be a great idea there
that's a very difficult terrain I've
flown recently flown across that I've
been in it it's like Afghanistan but
even even more difficult high mountains
ravines distant valleys no roads and a
long tribal tradition which is quite a
bit more aggressive than Afghanistan's
so now we're faced with the situation
but the people who committed the attacks
on the US on 911 of the people who
killed benazir bhutto who committed the
atrocities in Mumbai who have attacked
Islamabad in Lahore and who aren
doubtedly planning more attacks on other
countries and perhaps including the
United States they say they're going to
attack us again they're sitting in
afghan-pakistan so that it that's our
that to me is the core of the dilemma
you have this huge country second
largest Muslim country in the world
fifth or sixth largest country in the
world by population
not a failed state to get that out of
your minds it's a cliche but it is a
country that has tremendous
fragmentation problems and we need to
support Pakistan very strongly that's
not always a popular thing to do given
all the problems in Pakistan and
meanwhile we have to encourage them and
help them to go after these really bad
people
